lines.text: Will you be so kind, Mr Crane, with your camera, to take a picture of this regiment on this glorious hill, for we will always live in its shadow.
You're wounded, sir.
A red badge of courage... it's not like your book, old man. I would have run if I could have.
Why didn't you?
Because they were watching, my fellows; they didn't run.
Life is hunger. Life is anger. Life is pain and dirt. Your grandfather knew life. He didn't recommend it. That's why we're rich.
To be wealthy, warm, and well-thought of... that's what a man really wants, if he's honest. And you have it.
We've got the Yankees on the run!
Spaniards, sir; and they're falling back onto prepared positions.
Don't spoil it, son.
What are you thinking about, Craig?
My father. He gave me some advice, before I joined the regiment.
Was it good advice?
Yes.
Did you follow it?
No.
[first lines]
I miss you, boys. Been more that twenty years. My God, we were young. Well, it was a young country then, full of promise and hope. Anything was possible then if you were an American.
[last lines]
I'll see you boys soon. Adios compadres.

[Roosevelt has expressed concern over the upcoming attack]
Don't worry, colonel; you're the closest thing most of these boys have to a father. We won't let you down.

[after his shot was shot]
I haven't had a horse shot out from under me in 30 years.
[sigh]
It's still a Thrill.
For God's sake, follow the Colonel!
I killed a bear once.
[pause]
I didn't like it much.

[after shooting a Spaniard who tried to surrender]
He who has no stomach for this fight, let him depart.
Indian Bob, kill that German!
Whatever I see, I hit!
When we were good, and not misbehaving, she made us cheese grits!
This isn't a regulation war. That ain't how we do things here in the South.

[frustrated and waving a pistol as a captured German provides instructions on how to use a machine gun]
I can see it feeds from the right!

[before the final charge]
What are you thinking about now?
Naked women.
If it were up to me, we'd drive every European flag from this Hemisphere at bayonet point!
Mon dieu, help me, I feel faint.
Feel free. By all means, fall right over!

[greeting dignitaries at a party]
Oh, more good Republicans!
Where are the Spaniards? It says they've landed at... Daiquiri.
Daiquiri? Isn't that a new summer cocktail?
NOW you're getting the idea, Mr. Hay...
Alright, you sons of bitches - do it!

[examining the New York Journal's account of the Maine sinking]
I think you're a scoundrel, Randolph - completely without conscience.
What, did Freddie go too far?
You don't really think that those people blew up that boat, now do you?
A naval blockade is in the offing, gentlemen.
A naval blockade is hardly a war.
Furnish the pictures, Freddie, and I'll furnish the war!
Very good, Willy.
Well said, Randolph!
Thank you, Mr. Secretary.
Cheers.
Remember the Maine, and to HELL with Spain!
May we all be killed, wounded or promoted.
General, you were one of the finest cavalry officers in the Confederacy.

[shakes his head]
Let me tell you something... Bedford Forrest had 32 horses shot out from under him, but he killed 33 Yankees.
[chuckles]
Forrest was better!

[after leaving an officer's conference]
That General Shafter is way over his head... WAY over. And he's big as a house to boot!
I just hope you were polite in there, Daddy.
What if I wasn't? What the hell are they gonna do to me?
I just meant that...
Now, you listen to me, boy! I am a US Congressman, I am a volunteer, I am here on the personal request of the President of the United States... and I am a Reb!
I understand, Daddy...
Now listen to me very closely... I have got these Yankees by the long johns!
General Wheeler! I hope you won't mind this brief intrusion, but I'm Horatio Swayles. I was with the Union cavalry that opposed you in the fighting around Atlanta.
Nice to meet you. This is my son, William. You'll forgive me if I tell you that Atlanta isn't one of my fondest memories.
Well, of course...
[the Wheelers walk on]

[to William]
I should have killed that son of a bitch long ago to keep him from breeding!

[having tamed a horse Nash was unable to break]
Spirited mount!
Well, I'll be damned... Where'd he learn to ride like that?
Craig Wadsworth is the finest polo player in the country. Do you play polo?
Oh, yeah, every day, right after my bubble bath!

[after O'Neill and Funston's men accidentally fired on one another]
These are insurrectos! And I'm Major Funston! You killed some of my men!
MAJOR FUNSTON! I can't take it back. We're all going the same place, now let's get there together!

[examining an account of the Battle of Manila Bay]
He was your appointment, was he not?
Oh, I had a hand in it!
And it was your plan to have Dewey coal his warships and set sail for Manila Bay.
Secretary Long was on vacation in New England.
So, YOU took the initiative?
I suppose so... But that Commodore Dewey was like a wolfhound slipped from the leash, wasn't he, Leonard?
Ambitious, often overreaching, frequently insubordinate, brash... but, successful - this time. Don't try it with me!

[eating a stew]
You stole this hog!
[makes oinking noises, to the consternation of Wood and Roosevelt]
We caught the gator and the snake.
Snake?
Footless animal stew, sir.
[chuckles]
It is the duty, the honor, of the patrician class to lead its countrymen by the sword.
Any of you boys ever see a bullfight? The Spanish enjoy bullfighting. The Spaniards are a cruel people. Do any of you know what the greatest feat of arms in history is?
The defeat of the Texans at the Alamo?
WRONG! The Spanish conquest of Mexico. 900 Spanish soldiers under Hernan Cortes defeated 100,000 Aztec warriors! And they did this with SWORDS! And they raped all the women and took all of the gold.

[Nash and the buffalo soldier come up to Remington painting the battlefield]
Hey, painter man! Where's the 1st Cavalry?
How should I know? I'm a non-combatant, God damn it!

[listening to Hearst dictate a report]
There were no gleaming helmets! We're in the jungle.
Shut up and finish your painting, Freddie.
But it's not... true!
Truth is the first casualty of war, Freddie. You'd ought to know that.

[to Nash, grabbing his throat]
Nash! Where were you the night Roosevelt came in? Hmm? I know you are and I know what you did. You should have got out while you had the chance, because you ain't getting out now. If any of my men dies because of you, I'll have you pulled apart by horses! Understand? Savvy?
Captain, hadn't you better get down?
There ain't a Spanish bullet made that can kill me! Nash...
[is shot by a Spanish sniper]

[after O'Neill is killed]
I swear that I'll make people remember you, old man. Remember what you did for us. I'll build a statue if I have to!
All in all, Theodore, you're shaping up to be a competent officer. Don't let it go to your head.
No, sir. I shall not do that!

[after being wounded by Spanish artillery]
Like a hornet sting! YOU'LL HAVE TO DO BETTER THAN THAT!

[before the charge on San Juan Hill]
Buffalo soldiers! This what they pay you thirteen dollars a month for!

Our transport ships haven't even got here yet! And now I hear supplies are still aboard trains? And our quartermaster tells me he has no idea WHICH trains! I've never seen anything like it. My God, I've never seen anything like it in my lifetime!
That's because nothing like this has ever happened in your lifetime.

[after Kane, Tiffany and Wodsworth begin reciting Henry V's Agincourt speech]
What are they talking about?

[shrugs]
They're educated men.

[trying to convince Wood to be Colonel of the Rough Riders]
Come on, Leonard, you already know you're going. Why not at the head of the wildest mad cap regiment since the Mongols rode the Steppes?
Theodore, do you know that you're mad?
Well, it's never bothered him before...
Colonel Roosevelt, what do you think of this regiment, the Rough Riders?

I think this regiment could whip Caesar's Tenth Legion! I think they could ride with Genghis Khan! They are the best examples of American manhood. We have cowboys, Ivy Leaguers, football players, polo players, bronco busters, New York City policemen... and one man, I regret to say, who used to work for the Internal Revenue Service!
Are you Mr. Hearst?
Of course I'm Hearst.
An urgent dispatch, sir - from Washington.

[reads it closely, and his face goes wide with excitement]
WAR!
[Hearst and his entourage rush inside]
Artillery is always the only answer!
War's an argument! Best way to win that argument is to kill the other fella.
A man's gotta do what he has to do, Sara.
Yeah, and a woman's got to do everything else.

[describing the batttle to Teague]
Any American would give an arm to see this.

[to McKinley]
But don't worry too much about them people in the South. there's nothing they like better than a good fight.
[laughs]
Good day.
[He starts to leave]
Oh, we don't even celebrate the Fourth of July.
[Guffaws]
Maybe after this, we will.
You're gonna make these men murderers!
Gonna try!

[Drunkenly to Teague]
When the time comes, I'll walk to the sound of the guns.

[to Hay]
Well, God takes care of drunks, madmen, and the American army.

[Pointing out the Apache]
Look at that Indian. There ain't nuthin' human about him. He don't even talk.
He ain't got nuthin' to say.
But he's a wild Indian. What are you?
Sioux. You know, the ones who got Custer.
Hell, no one ever thought well of me my whole life.
